channel.title: Script engines for java
channel.description:
Is creating a script engine for say a rsps quite a task?
I've been reading up on it and it doesn't look too difficult but maybe I'm under-estimating it. I'm looking into doing it so I can learn another language like python, ruby or javascript, and it'd be pretty cool to make the application function from these scripts. Learning purposes basically
But what I don't understand is how everything can be handled through these scripts.
Any information on this topic?

item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Jmood, post:7, topic:542670”][quote author=xEthanx link=topic=661547.msg4422035#msg4422035 date=1398914798]
It’s not as bad as you might think, but it isn’t quick either. I haven’t done it personally but Kane handles game development for our RSPS and showed me articles that he followed that literally list all the protocol you’ll need for the entire server engine. I’m sure it’d be tedious, but worth it. Being able to fully understand the entirety of your server structure would be really nice, especially considering a lot of these clients and server sources that people just edit pieces of code from we’re written in like 2001, and are just disgusting looking. You’ve probably seen the bukkshit where they have methods called “method557” or classes called “Class5_Sub1_Sub3_Sub1_Sub2” or something like that. So to avoid that whole mess by creating your own system is definitely worth it.

Plus, if Kane can figure it out a lot of people can, lolz.

Edit: But yeah I know nothing about Ruby or Python, just Java. So I have no idea how powerful those languages are in comparison to Java, or if it’s the right way about programming an RSPS. I feel as if it’d be the same concept except I don’t even know if Ruby/Python are object-oriented languages lol, could make a big difference. Unless you’re just up for a challenge though, what’s the point really? The community behind Java is just insanely huge so help is readily available, and everyone’s pretty much guaranteed to have it installed.

Anyways, good luck if you give a try, you should cause there’s no harm in that.
[/quote]

If you want better names than use a client that has been renamed, those methods and class names are from the client being deobfucated to an extent. As for it being written in 2001 I am not sure how that would of been possible since RS2 didn’t come out until 2004.

If you want scripting than nothing wrong with using one that is already set to go, Ruby and Python would be fine or you can just keep everything in Java and use something like a module, plug-in, mod, ect, ect system. But if you insist on creating your own good luck![/quote]

That’s what I’m going for essentially, like a plugin system but I thought using another language will give me experience in something other than Java but just trying to set it up to work with game content at the moment.

Read full topic

The community behind Java is just insanely huge so help is readily available, and everyone’s pretty much guaranteed to have it installed.

Anyways, good luck if you give a try, you should cause there’s no harm in that.
[/quote]

If you want better names than use a client that has been renamed, those methods and class names are from the client being deobfucated to an extent. As for it being written in 2001 I am not sure how that would of been possible since RS2 didn’t come out until 2004.[/quote]
Yeah I guess that makes sense. It’s kind of a little late for me to change clients though. And I got 2001 from the comments at the beginning of the class files.

Read full topic

item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:6, topic:542670”]It’s not as bad as you might think, but it isn’t quick either. I haven’t done it personally but Kane handles game development for our RSPS and showed me articles that he followed that literally list all the protocol you’ll need for the entire server engine. I’m sure it’d be tedious, but worth it. Being able to fully understand the entirety of your server structure would be really nice, especially considering a lot of these clients and server sources that people just edit pieces of code from we’re written in like 2001, and are just disgusting looking. You’ve probably seen the bukkshit where they have methods called “method557” or classes called “Class5_Sub1_Sub3_Sub1_Sub2” or something like that. So to avoid that whole mess by creating your own system is definitely worth it.

Plus, if Kane can figure it out a lot of people can, lolz.

Edit: But yeah I know nothing about Ruby or Python, just Java. So I have no idea how powerful those languages are in comparison to Java, or if it’s the right way about programming an RSPS. I feel as if it’d be the same concept except I don’t even know if Ruby/Python are object-oriented languages lol, could make a big difference. Unless you’re just up for a challenge though, what’s the point really? The community behind Java is just insanely huge so help is readily available, and everyone’s pretty much guaranteed to have it installed.

Anyways, good luck if you give a try, you should cause there’s no harm in that.[/quote]

If you want better names than use a client that has been renamed, those methods and class names are from the client being deobfucated to an extent. As for it being written in 2001 I am not sure how that would of been possible since RS2 didn’t come out until 2004.

If you want scripting than nothing wrong with using one that is already set to go, Ruby and Python would be fine or you can just keep everything in Java and use something like a module, plug-in, mod, ect, ect system. But if you insist on creating your own good luck!

Read full topic

I’m sure it’d be tedious, but worth it. Being able to fully understand the entirety of your server structure would be really nice, especially considering a lot of these clients and server sources that people just edit pieces of code from we’re written in like 2001, and are just disgusting looking. item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:4, topic:542670”]To be honest, the ‘engine’ as you’ve described it is ultimately a mapping of actions to outcomes. That is, you might map an action (i.e., prospecting a rock, or more generally object option 2) to a script, and that script runs subject to some predicate being true.

For example: You map the using a bank booth to a handling method that sends a message to the user. The predicate might only return true if the user is within a certain location (i.e., within a bank that, in your server, is abandoned). So whenever a player clicks a bank booth object while standing in an abandoned bank, they get the message (which might be something like “This bank is not operating.”).
To complicate it a little further, you might want to chain handlers so that one action maps to zero to many handlers. You might also want to introduce the notion of priority, and finally the notion of either firing the action down the chain or aborting the action partway through the chain when appropriate.

For example, you might have the following actions for mining iron ore:
Priority 1: Mining iron ore in a particular location during a quest - when this handler’s predicate is true, the handler fires and the quest progress is updated. This is a special case, so it doesn’t fire the event further down the chain.
Priority 2: Regular iron ore mining. This is the default, and should always run if reached. You would likely place the regular action as the lowest priority so that special priority handlers have the chance to run when appropriate.

Importantly, a real game would have hundreds or thousands of handlers. So you need to use efficient data structures (typically structures that run in logarithmic time in the worst case – basically your tree structures). Otherwise the solution doesn’t scale up to those hundreds/thousands of handlers very well.

11pm brain dump. Don’t judge me too harshly.[/quote]

I see, well thanks for the explanation but I’m trying to get something simple working right now and just handle a couple of things through scripts.

For example: You map the using a bank booth to a handling method that sends a message to the user. The predicate might only return true if the user is within a certain location (i.e., within a bank that, in your server, is abandoned). So whenever a player clicks a bank booth object while standing in an abandoned bank, they get the message (which might be something like "This bank is not operating."). To complicate it a little further, you might want to chain handlers so that one action maps to zero to many handlers. You might also want to introduce the notion of priority, and finally the notion of either firing the action down the chain or aborting the action partway through the chain when appropriate.

These handlers, are they to execute the right script for the action?

Like if it was object clicking, it would be executing the script objectClick.py or have I got the wrong idea. Kinda confused on some of the terms used.

Read full topic

item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

To be honest, the ‘engine’ as you’ve described it is ultimately a mapping of actions to outcomes. That is, you might map an action (i.e., prospecting a rock, or more generally object option 2) to a script, and that script runs subject to some predicate being true.

For example: You map the using a bank booth to a handling method that sends a message to the user. The predicate might only return true if the user is within a certain location (i.e., within a bank that, in your server, is abandoned). So whenever a player clicks a bank booth object while standing in an abandoned bank, they get the message (which might be something like “This bank is not operating.”).
To complicate it a little further, you might want to chain handlers so that one action maps to zero to many handlers. You might also want to introduce the notion of priority, and finally the notion of either firing the action down the chain or aborting the action partway through the chain when appropriate.

For example, you might have the following actions for mining iron ore:
Priority 1: Mining iron ore in a particular location during a quest - when this handler’s predicate is true, the handler fires and the quest progress is updated. This is a special case, so it doesn’t fire the event further down the chain.
Priority 2: Regular iron ore mining. This is the default, and should always run if reached. You would likely place the regular action as the lowest priority so that special priority handlers have the chance to run when appropriate.

Importantly, a real game would have hundreds or thousands of handlers. So you need to use efficient data structures (typically structures that run in logarithmic time in the worst case – basically your tree structures). Otherwise the solution doesn’t scale up to those hundreds/thousands of handlers very well.

11pm brain dump. Don’t judge me too harshly.

Read full topic

item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I will say building the engine would be beyond actually picking what language you’d like to use, even if it’s Java. just make sure you understand your problem correctly, and the language you choose for your engine won’t even matter.

Read full topic

item.title: Script engines for java
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

Java has api’s for those scripting languages. Jython and JRuby, however you can define your own scripting language - given you know what you’re doing.

just parse the data the way you need.

Read full topic
